subject: Fix full backup/restore volume error with rbd backend
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-16 10:47:50.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/backup/drivers/ceph.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/99089fb43d1d305bb0a40ffb590bac61cb63165e', 'message': 'Fix full backup/restore volume error with rbd backend

When createing or restoring a backup of a large volume with rbd
backend, time-consuming operations like read/write/flush/fsync,
will block eventlet loop and cinder-backup service hangs
until it finished. It makes cinder-backup services unavailable for
a while. So using tpool to execute the time-consuming cmds to avoid
this suitation.

Change-Id: Idab0b64233c847da4b92299f2ec0448bb5abc2a3
'}]
commit_message:
Fix full backup/restore volume error with rbd backend

When createing or restoring a backup of a large volume with rbd
backend, time-consuming operations like read/write/flush/fsync,
will block eventlet loop and cinder-backup service hangs
until it finished. It makes cinder-backup services unavailable for
a while. So using tpool to execute the time-consuming cmds to avoid
this suitation.

Change-Id: Idab0b64233c847da4b92299f2ec0448bb5abc2a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/35/534235/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from eventlet import tpool tpool.execute(volume.write, zeroes) tpool.execute(volume.flush) tpool.execute(volume.write, zeroes) tpool.execute(volume.flush) data = tpool.execute(src.read, self.chunk_size) tpool.execute(dest.write, data) tpool.execute(dest.flush) data = tpool.execute(src.read, rem) tpool.execute(dest.write, data) tpool.execute(dest.flush) tpool.execute(os.fsync, fileno)
deleted_lines: volume.write(zeroes) volume.flush() volume.write(zeroes) volume.flush() data = src.read(self.chunk_size) dest.write(data) dest.flush() data = src.read(rem) dest.write(data) dest.flush() os.fsync(fileno)

subject: use tempest_run_stackviz to generate stackviz report
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-02-21 08:22:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/commit/453bb4f3e7f8b39b07267ae2ba9228b72da24dc0', 'message': 'use run_stackviz to generate stackviz report

When os_tempest is used locally or not in CI for
development and testing, it does not make any sense to generate
stackviz report each time. Adding run_stackviz makes sure
when it is enabled then it will run.

Change-Id: I4f9a6bcce7e1f4b7ebc873ee11f141d40f0d3e36
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2019-02-21 16:06:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/commit/31e8f6b3ee408af2d3279273e6a3228d52e49ad3', 'message': 'use tempest_run_stackviz to generate stackviz report

When os_tempest is used locally or not in CI for
development and testing, it does not make any sense to generate

commit_message:
use tempest_run_stackviz to generate stackviz report

When os_tempest is used locally or not in CI for
development and testing, it does not make any sense to generate
stackviz report each time. Adding tempest_run_stackviz makes sure
when it is enabled then it will run.

Change-Id: I4f9a6bcce7e1f4b7ebc873ee11f141d40f0d3e36
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_tempest refs/changes/60/638360/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: run_stackviz: true

commit_message:
Fix: cinder group-list not working with non-admin user

The all_tenants filter is passed to API when it's value is 0
(when not specified) which shouldn't be the case.
This patch only allows adding of all_tenants when specified
manually by user.

Change-Id: Ic7810c4d6e9f4be7c28c7a8778d57bb5ccb996a0
Closes-Bug: #1808621
Closes-Bug: #1808622
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/59/627359/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: resource_type = "groups" url = self._build_list_url(resource_type, search_opts=search_opts) return self._list(url, resource_type)
deleted_lines: query_string = utils.build_query_param(search_opts, sort=True) detail = "" if detailed: detail = "/detail" return self._list("/groups%s%s" % (detail, query_string), "groups")

subject: Use validate_legacy
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-02-10 12:47:14.000000000', 'files': ['manifests/agent/notification.pp', 'manifests/db/mysql.pp', 'manifests/config.pp', 'manifests/policy.pp', 'manifests/keystone/auth.pp'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer/commit/28afa466d74fffa567bbad12ec164ae097fd963a', 'message': 'Use validate_legacy

This changes all the puppet 3 validate_* functions
to use the validate_legacy function.

The validate_legacy function has been available since
about three years but require Puppet >= 4.4.0 and since
there is Puppet 4.10.12 as latest we should assume people
are running a fairly new Puppet 4 version.

This is the first step to then remove all validate function
calls and use proper types for parameter as described in spec [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568929/

Change-Id: I640d5ca592774601a252dbafbdc90bc98313055b
'}]
commit_message:
Use validate_legacy

This changes all the puppet 3 validate_* functions
to use the validate_legacy function.

The validate_legacy function has been available since
about three years but require Puppet >= 4.4.0 and since
there is Puppet 4.10.12 as latest we should assume people
are running a fairly new Puppet 4 version.

This is the first step to then remove all validate function
calls and use proper types for parameter as described in spec [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568929/

Change-Id: I640d5ca592774601a252dbafbdc90bc98313055b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceilometer refs/changes/49/636049/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: validate_legacy(String, 'validate_string', $password)

subject: Cleanup files and templates using smart sources
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-08-05 06:13:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_glance/commit/2bdb95aebc2939911b913cd243e99157a01859dc', 'message': 'Cleanup files and templates using smart sources

The files and templates we carry are almost always in a state of
maintenance. The upstream services are maintaining these files and
there's really no reason we need to carry duplicate copies of them. This
change removes all of the files we expect to get from the upstream
service. while the focus of this change is to remove configuration file
maintenance burdens it also allows the role to execute faster.

  * Source installs have the configuration files within the venv at
    "<<VENV_PATH>>/etc/<<SERVICE_NAME>>". The role will now link the
    default configuration path to this directory. When the service is
    upgraded the link will move to the new venv path.
  * Distro installs package all of the required configuration files.

To maintain our current capabilities to override configuration the
role will fetch files from the disk whenever an override is provided and
then push the fetched file back to the target using `config_template`.

Change-Id: I3e7283bf778a9d686f3ae500b289c1fb43b42b92
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2018-08-05 06:16:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_glance/commit/3a442e30bf7dbb93465c868196db4678e5edb586', 'message': 'Cleanup files and templates using smart sources

commit_message:
Cleanup files and templates using smart sources

The files and templates we carry are almost always in a state of
maintenance. The upstream services are maintaining these files and
there's really no reason we need to carry duplicate copies of them. This
change removes all of the files we expect to get from the upstream
service. while the focus of this change is to remove configuration file
maintenance burdens it also allows the role to execute faster.

  * Source installs have the configuration files within the venv at
    "<<VENV_PATH>>/etc/<<SERVICE_NAME>>". The role will now link the
    default configuration path to this directory. When the service is
    upgraded the link will move to the new venv path.
  * Distro installs package all of the required configuration files.

To maintain our current capabilities to override configuration the
role will fetch files from the disk whenever an override is provided and
then push the fetched file back to the target using `config_template`.

Change-Id: I3e7283bf778a9d686f3ae500b289c1fb43b42b92
Signed-off-by: cloudnull <kevin@cloudnull.com>

commit_message:
Use placement.inventory.inuse in report client

Since I9a833aa35d474caa35e640bbad6c436a3b16ac5e we've had the framework
for placement to return specific error codes allowing us to
differentiate among error conditions for oft-repeated status codes.
That change also included as its proof-of-concept a specific code for
the placement side of InventoryInUse - i.e. an attempt to delete an
inventory record for which there are existing allocations.

SchedulerReportClient was previously identifying this error condition by
parsing the text of the 409 response. With this change, it instead uses
the provided error code.

Change-Id: Ic621adcadf10cc607455eba48c4cb1882bde23fa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/39/568639/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.api.openstack.placement import errors as placement_errorsdef _check_inventory_in_use(resp): """Given an HTTP response, determine whether it represents the error condition where inventory was in use when we tried to delete it. If so, raise InventoryInUse. :raise InventoryInUse: If the response indicates an inventory-in-use error. if resp.status_code != 409: return err = resp.json()['errors'][0] if err['code'] == placement_errors.INVENTORY_INUSE: # The error detail includes the resource class and provider. raise exception.InventoryInUse(err['detail']) _check_inventory_in_use(result) _check_inventory_in_use(resp)
deleted_lines: import re_RE_INV_IN_USE = re.compile("Inventory for (.+) on resource provider " "(.+) in use")def _extract_inventory_in_use(body): """Given an HTTP response body, extract the resource classes that were still in use when we tried to delete inventory. :returns: String of resource classes or None if there was no InventoryInUse error in the response body. match = _RE_INV_IN_USE.search(body) if match: return match.group(1) return None rc = _extract_inventory_in_use(result.text) if rc is not None: raise exception.InventoryInUse( resource_classes=rc, resource_provider=rp_uuid, ) rc = _extract_inventory_in_use(resp.text) if rc is not None: raise exception.InventoryInUse( resource_classes=rc, resource_provider=rp_uuid, )

commit_message:
Resolve ``ValueError`` when mapping value contains a literal ``=``.

Example ``setup.cfg``::

    project_urls =
      Documentation = https://format-pipfile.readthedocs.io/en/latest/?badge=latest

Current result::

    $ ./setup.py
    ERROR:root:Error parsing
    Traceback (most recent call last):
      File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pbr/core.py", line 96, in pbr
        attrs = util.cfg_to_args(path, dist.script_args)
      File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pbr/util.py", line 258, in cfg_to_args
        kwargs = setup_cfg_to_setup_kwargs(config, script_args)
      File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pbr/util.py", line 336, in setup_cfg_to_setup_kwargs
        k, v = i.split(=)
    ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 2)
    error in setup command: Error parsing /Users/brandon/src/format-pipfile/setup.cfg: ValueError: too many values to unpack (expected 2)

After changes::

    $ ./setup.py egg_info
    [...]
    $ grep -i project-url *.egg-info/PKG-INFO
    [...]
    Project-URL: Documentation, https://format-pipfile.readthedocs.io/en/latest/?badge=latest
    [...]

add unit tests

    {1} pbr.tests.test_util.TestMapFieldsParsingScenarios.test_project_url_parsing(simple_project_urls) [0.034230s] ... ok
    {1} pbr.tests.test_util.TestMapFieldsParsingScenarios.test_project_url_parsing(query_parameters) [0.029791s] ... ok

Closes-Bug: #1817592
Change-Id: Ifd4c46111528d99dadee77d6aabed201d9e84bdb
Signed-off-by: Brandon LeBlanc <brandon@leblanc.codes>

added_lines: def config_from_ini(ini): config = {} if sys.version_info >= (3, 2): parser = configparser.ConfigParser() else: parser = configparser.SafeConfigParser() ini = textwrap.dedent(six.u(ini)) parser.readfp(io.StringIO(ini)) for section in parser.sections(): config[section] = dict(parser.items(section)) return config def test_extras_parsing(self): config = config_from_ini(self.config_text) class TestMapFieldsParsingScenarios(base.BaseTestCase): scenarios = [ ('simple_project_urls', { 'config_text': """ [metadata] project_urls = Bug Tracker = https://bugs.launchpad.net/pbr/ Documentation = https://docs.openstack.org/pbr/ Source Code = https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/pbr/ """, 'expected_project_urls': { 'Bug Tracker': 'https://bugs.launchpad.net/pbr/', 'Documentation': 'https://docs.openstack.org/pbr/', 'Source Code': 'https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/pbr/', }, }), ('query_parameters', { 'config_text': """ [metadata] project_urls = Bug Tracker = https://bugs.launchpad.net/pbr/?query=true Documentation = https://docs.openstack.org/pbr/?foo=bar Source Code = https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/pbr/commit/?id=hash """, 'expected_project_urls': { 'Bug Tracker': 'https://bugs.launchpad.net/pbr/?query=true', 'Documentation': 'https://docs.openstack.org/pbr/?foo=bar', 'Source Code': 'https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-dev/pbr/commit/?id=hash', }, }), ] def test_project_url_parsing(self): config = config_from_ini(self.config_text) kwargs = util.setup_cfg_to_setup_kwargs(config) self.assertEqual(self.expected_project_urls, kwargs['project_urls'])
deleted_lines: def config_from_ini(self, ini): config = {} if sys.version_info >= (3, 2): parser = configparser.ConfigParser() else: parser = configparser.SafeConfigParser() ini = textwrap.dedent(six.u(ini)) parser.readfp(io.StringIO(ini)) for section in parser.sections(): config[section] = dict(parser.items(section)) return config def test_extras_parsing(self): config = self.config_from_ini(self.config_text)

commit_message:
Karbor providers managed from deployment node

Karbor provider configs can be injected/managed from 'node_custom_config' var

openstack-infra.conf will still be created if no custom providers present

Closes-Bug #1814464

Change-Id: I500daae80596cb7b7342fd8d4affa8f901b24a13

added_lines: import collectionsfrom cinder.db.sqlalchemy import models def limit_check_project(self, context, resources, project_values=None, project_id=None): """Check values (usage + desired delta) against quota limits. For limits--this method checks that a set of proposed values are permitted by the limit restriction. This method will raise a QuotaResourceUnknown exception if a given resource is unknown or if it is not a simple limit resource. If any of the proposed values is over the defined quota, an OverQuota exception will be raised with the sorted list of the resources which are too high. Otherwise, the method returns nothing. :param context: The request context, for access checks :param resources: A dictionary of the registered resources :param project_values: Optional dict containing the resource values to check against project quota, e.g. {'instances': 1, 'cores': 2, 'memory_mb': 512} :param project_id: Optional project_id for scoping the limit check to a different project than in the context """ if project_values is None: project_values = {} if not project_values: raise exception.Invalid( 'Must specify at least one of project_values ' 'for the limit check.') # Ensure no value is less than zero unders = [key for key, val in project_values.items() if val < 0] if unders: raise exception.InvalidQuotaValue(unders=sorted(unders)) # Get a set of all keys for calling _get_quotas() so we get all of the # resource limits we need. all_keys = set(project_values) # If project_id is None, then we use the project_id in context if project_id is None: project_id = context.project_id # per user quotas, project quota limits (for quotas that have # user-scoping, limits for the project) quotas = self._get_quotas(context, resources, all_keys, project_id=project_id) print("!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!get current project quotas========================") print(quotas) overs = [] for key in project_values.keys(): if (0 <= quotas[key] < project_values[key]): overs.append(key) if overs: print("quota exceed======================%s" % overs) raise exception.OverQuota(overs=sorted(overs)) def _get_usages(self, context, resources, project_id): """Get usages of specified resources. This function is called to get resource usages for validating quota limit creates or updates in the os-quota-sets API and for displaying resource usages in the os-used-limits API. This function is not used for checking resource usage against quota limits. :param context: The request context for access checks :param resources: The dict of Resources for which to get usages :param project_id: The project_id for scoping the usage count :returns: A dict containing resources and their usage information, for example: {'project_id': 'project-uuid', 'user_id': 'user-uuid', 'instances': {'in_use': 5}, 'fixed_ips': {'in_use': 5}} """ usages = {} for resource in resources.values(): # NOTE(melwitt): We should skip resources that are not countable, # such as AbsoluteResources. if not isinstance(resource, CountableResource): continue if resource.name in usages: # This is needed because for any of the resources: # ('instances', 'cores', 'ram'), they are counted at the same # time for efficiency (query the instances table once instead # of multiple times). So, a count of any one of them contains # counts for the others and we can avoid re-counting things. continue count = resource.count_as_dict(context, project_id) # Example count_as_dict() return value: # {'project': {'instances': 5}, # 'user': {'instances': 2}} counted_resources = count['project'].keys() for res in counted_resources: count_value = count['project'][res] usages[res] = {'in_use': count_value} return usages project_usages = self._get_usages(context, resources, project_id) in_use=usage.get('in_use', 0), ) def _get_quotas(self, context, resources, keys, project_id=None): :param keys: A list of the desired quotas to retrieve. if k in desired} def __init__(self, name, count_as_dict, flag=None): self.count_as_dict = count_as_dict def limit_check_project(self, context, project_values=None, project_id=None): """Check values against quota limits. For limits--this method checks that a set of proposed values are permitted by the limit restriction. This method will raise a QuotaResourceUnknown exception if a given resource is unknown or if it is not a simple limit resource. If any of the proposed values is over the defined quota, an OverQuota exception will be raised with the sorted list of the resources which are too high. Otherwise, the method returns nothing. :param context: The request context, for access checks :param project_values: Optional dict containing the resource values to check against project quota, e.g. {'instances': 1, 'cores': 2, 'memory_mb': 512} :param user_values: Optional dict containing the resource values to check against user quota, e.g. {'instances': 1, 'cores': 2, 'memory_mb': 512} :param project_id: Optional project_id for scoping the limit check to a different project than in the context """ return self._driver.limit_check_project( context, self.resources, project_values=project_values, project_id=project_id) def check_deltas(self, context, deltas, *count_args, **count_kwargs): """Check usage delta against quota limits. This does a Quotas.count_as_dict() followed by a Quotas.limit_check_project_and_user() using the provided deltas. :param context: The request context, for access checks :param deltas: A dict of {resource_name: delta, ...} to check against the quota limits :param count_args: Optional positional arguments to pass to count_as_dict() :param count_kwargs: Optional keyword arguments to pass to count_as_dict() :param check_project_id: Optional project_id for scoping the limit check to a different project than in the context :raises: exception.OverQuota if the limit check exceeds the quota limits """ # We can't do f(*args, kw=None, **kwargs) in python 2.x check_project_id = count_kwargs.pop('check_project_id', None) check_kwargs = collections.defaultdict(dict) count_kwargs['project_id'] = context.project_id if check_project_id is not None: count_kwargs['project_id'] = check_project_id for resource in deltas: # If we already counted a resource in a batch count, avoid # unnecessary re-counting and avoid creating empty dicts in # the defaultdict. if resource in check_kwargs.get('project_values', {}): continue print("!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!start to invoke count as dict for resource %s" % resource) count = self.count_as_dict(context, resource, *count_args, **count_kwargs) print("!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!current value for resource: %s" % count) for res in count.get('project', {}): if res in deltas: total = int(count['project'][res]) + deltas[res] check_kwargs['project_values'][res] = total if check_project_id is not None: check_kwargs['project_id'] = check_project_id try: print("!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!required resouces: %s" % check_kwargs['project_values']) self.limit_check_project(context, **check_kwargs) except exception.OverQuota as exc: raise exc def count_as_dict(self, context, resource, *args, **kwargs): """Count a resource and return a dict. For countable resources, invokes the count_as_dict() function and returns its result. Arguments following the context and resource are passed directly to the count function declared by the resource. :param context: The request context, for access checks. :param resource: The name of the resource, as a string. :returns: A dict containing the count(s) for the resource, for example: {'project': {'instances': 2, 'cores': 4, 'ram': 1024}, 'user': {'instances': 1, 'cores': 2, 'ram': 512}} another example: {'user': {'key_pairs': 5}} """ # Get the resource res = self.resources.get(resource) if not res or not hasattr(res, 'count_as_dict'): raise exception.QuotaResourceUnknown(unknown=[resource]) return res.count_as_dict(context, kwargs.pop('project_id'), *args, **kwargs) def _volume_count(context, project_id): return db.get_resource_counts(context, "volumes", models.Volume.id, project_id=project_id) def _volume_count_on_type(resource, type_id): def decorator(context, project_id): return db.get_resource_counts(context, resource, models.Volume.id, project_id=project_id, type_id=type_id) return decorator def _volume_gigabyte_count(context, project_id): return db.get_resource_counts(context, "gigabytes", models.Volume.size, project_id=project_id) def _volume_gigabyte_count_on_type(resource, type_id): def decorator(context, project_id): return db.get_resource_counts(context, resource, models.Volume.size, project_id=project_id, type_id=type_id) return decorator if self._resources: return self._resources argses = [('per_volume_gigabytes', None, 'per_volume_size_limit'), # TODO: QUOTA: Now we use countable resource for volume resources. result['volumes'] = CountableResource("volumes", _volume_count, "quota_volumes") result['gigabytes'] = CountableResource("gigabytes", _volume_gigabyte_count, "quota_gigabytes") for part_name in ('snapshots'): # TODO: QUOTA: Now we use countable resource for volume resources. for volume_type in volume_types.values(): # volume per type quota_name = "%s_%s" % ("volumes", volume_type['name']) result[quota_name] = CountableResource( quota_name, _volume_count_on_type(quota_name, volume_type['id'])) # gigabytes per type quota_name = "%s_%s" % ("gigabytes", volume_type['name']) result[quota_name] = CountableResource( quota_name, _volume_gigabyte_count_on_type(quota_name, volume_type['id'])) self._resources = result

commit_message:
Add overbooking quota driver

Add a new quota_driver: OverbookingDbQuotaDriver, that's
largely based on the existing DbQuotaDriver.

The main difference is that it not only checks project quota like
the original driver, but also checks if aggregate usage of projects
within a domain does not exceed domain's quota.

Driver could be enabled by adding this to the cinder.conf:

  quota_driver = cinder.quota.OverbookingDbQuotaDriver

Change-Id: Iaca7fb0311129f5e8316753279caae4cb378af11

commit_message:
Edits to Cinder Block Storage Overview

I find the existing wording in this paragraph is too abstract and could
lead the reader to be confused about what is being stated. For example,
"provides an infrastructure for managing volumes" isn't really clear as
"infrastructure" implies HW when the solution is SW. Therefore, the
objective is to provide additional clarity with the least amount of
additional detail. I also made some gramatical changes (commas before
"and" removed) and made the capitalization more consistent.

Best,

Hagen

Change-Id: If2b73afc754df50be5e5a551354b7f3e0fbe9f5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/24/533324/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Cinder Block Storage Service OverviewThe OpenStack Block Storage Service (Cinder) interacts with OpenStack Compute (Nova) to provide persistent storage (LUNs or Volumes) on which a virtual machine can be provisioned or which can be added to support applications running on an existing virtual machine. Cinder enables management of volume types which may be vendor specific based on the storage array or include features such as encryption. Cinder also offers storage services such as backup, snapshots and replication. The Block Storage Service consists of the following components: Accepts API requests and routes them to the ``cinder-volume`` for Interacts directly with the Block Storage Service and processes and write requests sent to the Block Storage Service to maintain state. It can allocate storage from a variety of storage providers through a vendor specific driver architecture. The ``cinder-backup`` service provides backup volumes of any type to a backup software application or service. Like the ``cinder-volume`` service, it can interact with a variety of storage providers through a vendor specific driver Routes information between the Block Storage processes.
deleted_lines: Cinder Block Storage service overviewThe OpenStack Block Storage service (Cinder) adds persistent storage to a virtual machine. Block Storage provides an infrastructure for managing volumes, and interacts with OpenStack Compute to provide volumes for instances. The service also enables management of volume snapshots, and volume types. The Block Storage service consists of the following components: Accepts API requests, and routes them to the ``cinder-volume`` for Interacts directly with the Block Storage service, and processes and write requests sent to the Block Storage service to maintain state. It can interact with a variety of storage providers through a driver architecture. The ``cinder-backup`` service provides backing up volumes of any type to a backup storage provider. Like the ``cinder-volume`` service, it can interact with a variety of storage providers through a driver Routes information between the Block Storage processes.

subject: 3PAR - Fix temp snapshot that remains post online copy
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-11-30 14:03:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/3d7b1c27365e301386b76f4594d014b86cb57493', 'message': '3PAR - Fix temp snapshot that remains post online copy

Issue
=====
For asynchronous tasks such as online copy,
driver creates a temporary snapshot which
remains on the array even after completion of
online copy task. This is highly undesirable as
over a period of time temporary snapshots can
unnecessarily occupy the resources on the array.

Fix
===
For any asynchronous task that is invoked from
driver code on 3PAR using WSAPI, corresponding
task id is returned which is presently not being
used. If the task id and operation context is
saved by the driver and the task is tracked on a
separate thread, any action that is required
post-operation can be performed – removal of
temporary snapshot in this case.

Change-Id: I7a6b26be5e9567c82d44b1f0eb3b8340ff15daea
Closes-Bug: #1735053

separate thread, any action that is required
post-operation can be performed – removal of
temporary snapshot in this case.

commit_message:
3PAR - Fix temp snapshot that remains post online copy

Issue
=====
For asynchronous tasks such as online copy,
driver creates a temporary snapshot which
remains on the array even after completion of
online copy task. This is highly undesirable as
over a period of time temporary snapshots can
unnecessarily occupy the resources on the array.

Fix
===
For any asynchronous task that is invoked from
driver code on 3PAR using WSAPI, corresponding
task id is returned which is presently not being
used. If the task id and operation context is
saved by the driver and the task is tracked on a
separate thread, any action that is required
post-operation can be performed – removal of
temporary snapshot in this case.

Change-Id: I7a6b26be5e9567c82d44b1f0eb3b8340ff15daea
Closes-Bug: #1735053
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/85/524185/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import threading import time from cinder import exception from cinder.i18n import _ from cinder import utils from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_utils import importutils hpe3parclient = importutils.try_import("hpe3parclient") if hpe3parclient: from hpe3parclient import client from hpe3parclient import exceptions as hpeexceptions LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) CONF = cfg.CONF # TODO: This should be moved to some common place MIN_CLIENT_VERSION = '4.2.0' class TaskTrackingThread(threading.Thread): def __init__(self, task_tracker): super(TaskTrackingThread, self).__init__() self._task_tracker = task_tracker def run(self): self._task_tracker.track_tasks() class TaskTracker(object): def __init__(self, driver): self._driver = driver self._untracked_q = [] self._3par_client = None self._tracked_q = [] self._stop_tracking = False self._worker_thread = TaskTrackingThread(self) self._lock = threading.Lock() @utils.trace def start_tracking(self): self._worker_thread.start() @utils.trace def stop_tracking(self): self._stop_tracking = True @utils.trace def add_task_listener(self, task_listener): with self._lock: # Add listener to un-tracked queue to be picked up # by worker thread self._untracked_q.append(task_listener) def _queue_up_waiting_listeners(self): """ Moves unprocessed task listeners to in-process queue :return: """ with self._lock: LOG.debug("TaskTracker::_queue_up_waiting_listeners: " "len(self._untracked_q)=%s" % len(self._untracked_q)) if self._untracked_q: LOG.debug("Moving listeners from untracked to tracked queue\n" "[untracked=%s] [tracked=%s]" % (self._untracked_q, self._tracked_q)) self._tracked_q += self._untracked_q self._untracked_q[:] = [] LOG.info("Listener(s) moved to tracked queue...\n%s" % self._tracked_q) @utils.trace def _cleanup_task_listeners(self, processed_q): """ Iterates over the list of processed task listener and remove them one by one from in-process queue :param processed_q: list of processed listeners :return: """ for task_listener in processed_q: self._tracked_q.remove(task_listener) @utils.trace def _get_task_info(self, task_id): config = self._driver.configuration try: LOG.debug("Connecting to 3PAR...") self._3par_client.login(config.hpe3par_username, config.hpe3par_password) LOG.info("Getting task info for task_id=%s" % task_id) return self._3par_client.getTask(task_id) except hpeexceptions.HTTPUnauthorized as ex: msg = (_("Failed to Login to 3PAR (%(url)s) because %(err)s") % {'url': config.hpe3par_api_url, 'err': ex}) LOG.error(msg) raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=msg) finally: self._3par_client.logout() @utils.trace def _get_3par_client(self, timeout=None): config = self._driver.configuration hpe3par_api_url = config.hpe3par_api_url cl = client.HPE3ParClient(hpe3par_api_url, timeout=timeout) client_version = hpe3parclient.version if client_version < MIN_CLIENT_VERSION: ex_msg = (_('Invalid hpe3parclient version found (%(found)s). ' 'Version %(minimum)s or greater required. Run "pip' ' install --upgrade python-3parclient" to upgrade' ' the hpe3parclient.') % {'found': client_version, 'minimum': MIN_CLIENT_VERSION}) LOG.error(ex_msg) raise exception.InvalidInput(reason=ex_msg) return cl @utils.trace def track_tasks(self): """ This function is invoked on a separate thread and does the following: 1. Moves the unprocessed listeners to in-process queue for processing 2. Iterates over in-process queue and queries for status of each task 3. Notifies the listener with the status of the task 4. If status is active, leaves tracking on for that task 5. If status is other than active, stops tracking for that task :return: """ config = self._driver.configuration while not self._stop_tracking: # Allow Cinder operation to add task listener for task # tracking while this thread sleeps for 10 seconds time.sleep(config.hpe3par_poll_unprocessed_tasks_after_time) # Move unprocessed listeners to in-process listener queue self._queue_up_waiting_listeners() # If nothing to process, wait for some time if not self._tracked_q: continue self._3par_client = self._get_3par_client() # Queue to keep track of listeners that have been processed and # need not be tracked. processed_q = [] for task_listener in self._tracked_q: try: task_info = self._get_task_info(task_listener._task_id) except Exception as ex: msg = "Failed to get task information: %s" % ex LOG.error(msg) # Mark listener as processed to stop tracking processed_q.append(task_listener) continue try: if task_info['status'] == self._3par_client.TASK_ACTIVE: task_listener.task_in_progress(task_info, self._3par_client) continue if task_info['status'] == self._3par_client.TASK_DONE: task_listener.task_completed(task_info, self._3par_client) elif task_info['status'] == self._3par_client.TASK_FAILED: task_listener.task_failed(task_info, self._3par_client) elif task_info['status'] == \ self._3par_client.TASK_CANCELLED: task_listener.task_cancelled(task_info, self._3par_client) except Exception as ex: LOG.error(ex) # In case of exception from active task listener, add it # for removal by just ignoring the exception and continuing # with the next listener pass processed_q.append(task_listener) # Remove those task listeners whose tasks are not active anymore self._cleanup_task_listeners(processed_q)

commit_message:
Reject QoS minimum bandwidth rule updates for bound ports as NotImplemented

Updating QoS policies and rules backed by resources tracked in Placement
is a complex task, which was left out of scope for the Stein release.
Of course this is only relevant for policies/rules already in use on
bound ports. Rules of unbound ports can still be updated freely.

Please note this patch cannot catch all possible problems. There will
always be a time window between the allocation committed to Placement
and Nova sending the port binding request to Neutron. If the policy or
rule is changed in this window we cannot do anything against it.

APIImpact: Reject QoS minimum bandwidth policy/rule updates for bound
           ports as NotImplemented

Change-Id: I477edb0ae35b385ac776a58195f22382e2fce4ed
Partial-Bug: #1578989
See-Also: https://review.openstack.org/502306 (nova spec)
See-Also: https://review.openstack.org/508149 (neutron spec)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/70/636970/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- other: - | Neutron server now rejects (as ``NotImplementedError``) updates of ``minimum_bandwidth`` QoS rules if the rule is already in effect on bound ports. Implementing updates will require updates to Placement allocations and possibly migrating servers where the new ``minimum_bandwidth`` can be satisifed.

Setup Release Goal Folder for Train

Change-Id: I28d114142f79d1bf9ef4783d056b8605f3e471a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/76/638676/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ===== Train ===== .. toctree:: :glob: :maxdepth: 1 *

subject: Multipath tempest scenarios
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-31 11:51:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/fdd381219b9a902228b5a0618452d7a2d8c52b0e', 'message': 'Multipath tempest scenarios

In order to validate the robustness of the iSCSI multipath code in
OpenStack we require harsher tests than those we have, since they only
test the "happy code path".

This patch adds error injecting tests with validation to confirm there
are no leftovers after an attach or detach failure.

We are testing create volume from image and attaching a volume to an
instance under the following networking error scenarios:

 - No errors
 - All paths have 10% incoming packets dropped
 - All paths have 20% incoming packets dropped
 - All paths have 100% incoming packets dropped
 - Half the paths have 20% incoming packets dropped
 - The other half of the paths have 20% incoming packets dropped
 - Half the paths have 100% incoming packets dropped
 - The other half of the paths have 100% incoming packets dropped

There are single execution versions as well as 10 consecutive operations
variants.

Proposed tests are not in line with the tempest mission since they are
not meant to be run in a production environment due to their disruptive
nature while injecting errors.  They need to be run sequentially and
without any other operations running on the deployment.  They also run
sudo commands via local bash or SSH for the verification and error
generation bits.

Recommended configuration in local.conf for single node devstack is:

  [[post-config|$CINDER_CONF]]
  [multipath-backend]
  use_multipath_for_image_xfer=true

  [[post-config|$NOVA_CONF]]
  [libvirt]
  volume_use_multipath = True

  [[post-config|$KEYSTONE_CONF]]
  [token]
  expiration = 14400

  [[test-config|$TEMPEST_CONFIG]]
  [volume-feature-enabled]
  multipath = True
  [volume]
  build_interval = 10
  multipath_type = $MULTIPATH_VOLUME_TYPE
  backend_protocol_tcp_port = 3260
  multipath_backend_addresses = $STORAGE_BACKEND_IP1,$STORAGE_BACKEND_IP2

And the interesting tests can be run from /opt/stack/tempest with:
  $ OS_TEST_TIMEOUT=7200 ostestr -r 'cinder.tests.tempest.scenario.test_multipath.TestMultipath.test_(create_volumes|attach_detach_many)_with_errors_*' --serial -- -f

In order to validate the robustness of the iSCSI multipath code in
OpenStack we require harsher tests than those we have, since they only
test the "happy code path".

This patch adds error injecting tests with validation to confirm there
are no leftovers after an attach or detach failure.

We are testing create volume from image and attaching a volume to an
instance under the following networking error scenarios:

 - No errors
 - All paths have 10% incoming packets dropped
 - All paths have 20% incoming packets dropped

 - The other half of the paths have 100% incoming packets dropped

variants.

without any other operations running on the deployment.  They also run

generation bits.

commit_message:
Multipath tempest scenarios

In order to validate the robustness of the iSCSI multipath code in
OpenStack we require harsher tests than those we have, since they only
test the "happy code path".

This patch adds error injecting tests with validation to confirm there
are no leftovers after an attach or detach failure and an appropriate
explanation in the devref documentation.

We are testing create volume from image and attaching a volume to an
instance under the following networking error scenarios:

 - No errors
 - All paths have 10% incoming packets dropped
 - All paths have 20% incoming packets dropped
 - All paths have 100% incoming packets dropped
 - Half the paths have 20% incoming packets dropped
 - The other half of the paths have 20% incoming packets dropped
 - Half the paths have 100% incoming packets dropped
 - The other half of the paths have 100% incoming packets dropped

There are single execution versions as well as 10 consecutive operations
variants.

Proposed tests are not in line with the tempest mission since they are
not meant to be run in a production environment due to their disruptive
nature while injecting errors.  They need to be run sequentially and
without any other operations running on the deployment.  They also run
sudo commands via local bash or SSH for the verification and error
generation bits.

Recommended configuration in local.conf for single node devstack is:

  [[post-config|$CINDER_CONF]]
  [multipath-backend]
  use_multipath_for_image_xfer=true

  [[post-config|$NOVA_CONF]]
  [libvirt]
  volume_use_multipath = True

  [[post-config|$KEYSTONE_CONF]]
  [token]
  expiration = 14400

  [[test-config|$TEMPEST_CONFIG]]
  [volume-feature-enabled]
  multipath = True
  [volume]
  build_interval = 10
  multipath_type = $MULTIPATH_VOLUME_TYPE
  backend_protocol_tcp_port = 3260
  multipath_backend_addresses = $STORAGE_BACKEND_IP1,$STORAGE_BACKEND_IP2

And the interesting tests can be run from /opt/stack/tempest with:
  $ OS_TEST_TIMEOUT=7200 ostestr -r 'cinder.tests.tempest.scenario.test_multipath.TestMultipath.test_(create_volumes|attach_detach_many)_with_errors_*' --serial -- -f

Change-Id: Id5188e26a6b52f5d00a6dc8ff52a7e1b0c188345
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/45/469445/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cinder_features = [ cfg.BoolOpt('multipath', default=False, help='Run multipath scenario. These are not normal tempest ' 'tests, so be sure to know what you are doing.'), ] cinder_options = [ # Multipath configuration options cfg.StrOpt('multipath_type', default=None, help='Volume Type for the multipath backend. Default value ' 'assumes single backend, multipath being the default ' 'volume type, or all backends supporting multipath. ' 'For Cinder tests the backend needs to have ' 'use_multipath_for_image_xfer set to true in cinder.conf,' 'and Nova needs to be properly configured for ' 'attach/detach tests to work.'), cfg.StrOpt('ssh_username', default=None, help='SSH username on Cinder and Nova hosts with sudo ' 'privileges. SSH connection is used to verify that no ' 'leftovers remain after the multipath scenario.'), cfg.StrOpt('ssh_password', default=None, help='SSH password for ssh_username on Cinder and Nova hosts. ' 'If using a private key is preferred, then configuration ' 'option ssh_private_key should be used instead.'), cfg.StrOpt('ssh_private_key', default=None, help='SSH private key for ssh_username on Cinder and Nova ' 'hosts. It can be either a string with the actual key or ' 'a path to the file key. If using a password is ' 'preferred then configuration option ssh_private_key ' 'should be used instead.'), cfg.StrOpt('backend_protocol_tcp_port', default=None, help='Source TCP port used for the protocol used to access the ' 'storage backend. If defined this will narrow the error ' 'injection to just this port. For example port 3260 for ' 'iSCSI connections.'), cfg.ListOpt('server_addresses', default=None, help='Cinder and Nova server IPs. Defaults to an ' 'all_in_one deployment which means multipath tests will ' 'use bash instead of SSH to run commands.'), cfg.ListOpt('multipath_backend_addresses', default=None, help='Storage array servers IPs or hostnames.'), cfg.ListOpt('multipath_cleanup_command', default=None, help='Command to run after each multipath scenario test for ' 'cleanup.'),

commit_message:
add python 3.7 unit test job

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: Ia1bc00770fe99f044d492c5dd18349373b8602a4
Story: #2004073
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient refs/changes/36/610036/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py37,py27,pep8

Update ansible to the latest stable release

Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin@cloudnull.com>

commit_message:
Remove docs build before building docs

The docs build can break if there's some stray data from a previous
build, such as if one builds on master, then switches to a stable
branch. Remove the docs build directory before building the docs to
start from a clean state.

Change-Id: Ia2814135ed3c8f98034b0fbb8c24ccaae6ac91df
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/62/638662/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: commands = rm -rf doc/build sphinx-build -b html -W doc/source doc/build/html

commit_message:
Fix mocks in unit tests

We should not use @mock.patch and @mock.patch.object for setUp methods.
They will be ignored for most cases. This patch adds mocks explicitly
into the setUp methods.

Change-Id: I3a1a3fdbe811d55ab9221d842bedec1c57ee4484

subject: Allow current driver to rename temp vol
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-01-15 21:35:09.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/volume/manager.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/volume/test_volume_migration.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/9e58a19a1b2b3e7522605c718fa01077b655e3b6', 'message': "Allow current driver to rename temp vol

Prior to this change, volume migration completion only calls the
remote driver's update_migrated_volume() manager method to give that
driver a chance to rename the backend volume (if they are sensitive
to looking up the volume by name property, for example). This is fine
for retype operations where the target volume resides in such a driver.
But if the source volume driver has the same sensitivity, then what
happens for a retype is that the volume properties and metadata get
swapped and the original volume gets deleted, but the delete operation
ends up not doing anything because the volume cannot be found.
The source volume is left orphaned an unmanged on the backend.

This change simply calls the current manager's  update_migrate_volume()
with the volume and new_volume parameters swapped. This allows
analgous backend updates and model data updates to be made for the
original volume, and fixes the existig assymetry in swapping volume
properties, but only updating one of the volumes.

Change-Id: I6098c2a0f1dbcddd6e79a0455ceed13d0da58dd2
Closes-Bug: #1743008
"}]
commit_message:
Allow current driver to rename temp vol

Prior to this change, volume migration completion only calls the
remote driver's update_migrated_volume() manager method to give that
driver a chance to rename the backend volume (if they are sensitive
to looking up the volume by name property, for example). This is fine
for retype operations where the target volume resides in such a driver.
But if the source volume driver has the same sensitivity, then what
happens for a retype is that the volume properties and metadata get
swapped and the original volume gets deleted, but the delete operation
ends up not doing anything because the volume cannot be found.
The source volume is left orphaned an unmanged on the backend.

This change simply calls the current manager's  update_migrate_volume()
with the volume and new_volume parameters swapped. This allows
analgous backend updates and model data updates to be made for the
original volume, and fixes the existig assymetry in swapping volume
properties, but only updating one of the volumes.

Change-Id: I6098c2a0f1dbcddd6e79a0455ceed13d0da58dd2
Closes-Bug: #1743008

commit_message:
Add static redirects for constraints

Ultimately we'll do this dynamically but as a POC lets use the existing
.htaccess file[1] to add them statically.  This allows us to test the
end results while we work out how to do this correctly *and* preserve
the current redirect for shade.

[1] This isn't working ATM as until https://review.openstack.org/#/c/638527/
    has merged and puppet has been run we don't allow allow any options
    in .htaccess.

Change-Id: I3a7d8f8af3d0f1301cbdbcaa5a46e9eb5672a151

commit_message:
Use tox 3.1.1 fixes

By 3.1.1, tox had fixed:
- [1] which mishandled the basepython directive.
- ignoring PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE [2]

Require this version and remove the workarounds.

See ML thread [3] for some details

[1] https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/issues/477
[2] https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/commit/336f4f6bd8b53223f940fc5cfc43b1bbd78d4699
[3] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-July/thread.html#132075

Change-Id: I87cbf4b26bdd40a8b7a699966e1ace838a2491de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/placement refs/changes/97/636997/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: minversion = 3.1.1# Automatic envs (pyXX) will use the python version appropriate to that # env and ignore basepython inherited from [testenv]. That's what we # want, and we don't need to be warned about it. ignore_basepython_conflict = Truebasepython = python3

subject: tox: Don't write byte code (maybe)
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-02-14 15:55:18.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/placement/commit/9e5436efabb450c70652f488bf70a1ec40b40df4', 'message': "tox: Don't write byte code (maybe)

In tox versions after 3.0.0rc1 [1], setting the environment variable
PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE will cause tox not to write .pyc files, which
means you don't have to delete them, which makes things faster.

In older tox versions, the env var is ignored.

If we bump the minimum tox version to something later than 3.0.0rc1, we
can remove the commands that find and remove .pyc files.

[1] https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/commit/336f4f6bd8b53223f940fc5cfc43b1bbd78d4699

Change-Id: Id9a97af032a2dbefdc50057270368ad087e6bb5f
"}]
commit_message:
tox: Don't write byte code (maybe)

In tox versions after 3.0.0rc1 [1], setting the environment variable
PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE will cause tox not to write .pyc files, which
means you don't have to delete them, which makes things faster.

In older tox versions, the env var is ignored.

If we bump the minimum tox version to something later than 3.0.0rc1, we
can remove the commands that find and remove .pyc files.

[1] https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/commit/336f4f6bd8b53223f940fc5cfc43b1bbd78d4699

Change-Id: Id9a97af032a2dbefdc50057270368ad087e6bb5f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/placement refs/changes/95/636995/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(efried): This is only effective in tox versions after 3.0.0rc1 # https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/commit/336f4f6bd8b53223f940fc5cfc43b1bbd78d4699 PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE=1

commit_message:
Remove the private option from include_role

The private option on include role was never implemented and
will no longer be developed. This change removes the option
so ansible no longer raises a deprecation warning.

Change-Id: I11ca7c3beed3bdabd6fcb517242a41180d1a4e63
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin@cloudnull.com>

commit_message:
Fix run-tempest role unrecognized arguments error

In case tempest_test_regex variable was set, run-tempest role
was missing "--regex=" argument which resulted in unrecognized
arguments error.

commit_message:
Adds check for duplicate alloc_cands

This patch adds a check for duplicate allocation candidates in
granular requests scenarios. To check the duplication, the __eq__ and
and the __hash__ operators are added both to AllocationRequestResource
class and to AllocationRequest class.

Change-Id: I8b5b0212077ca930ee69d3f1c349f41433bae68e
Closes-Bug: #1817458

commit_message:
Adds tests for granular single shared rp request

This patch adds a test for granular single shared resource provider
request, which turned out to be broken. Namely, we get duplicate
allocation requests when shared resource is requested alone.

Change-Id: Ia89e011fb51a41db9b7296ab357c36556d7c8fba
Related-Bug: #1817458

commit_message:
quota: remove QuotaEngine.register_resources()

The QuotaEngine.register_resources() method was not necessary. I've
simply added a resources kwarg to the QuotaEngine constructor and we now
construct the dict of resource objects to initialize the resources the
quota engine cares about.

One more method to the QuotaDriver, gone.

Change-Id: I818bbfb9493714341283042a21d5aefd90c094cb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/13/615613/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: def __init__(self, quota_driver=None): """Initialize a Quota object.""" self._resources = {} def register_resources(self, resources): """Register a list of resources.""" for resource in resources: self.register_resource(resource) QUOTAS = QuotaEngine() resources = [ CountableResource('instances', _instances_cores_ram_count, 'instances'), CountableResource('cores', _instances_cores_ram_count, 'cores'), CountableResource('ram', _instances_cores_ram_count, 'ram'), CountableResource('security_groups', _security_group_count, 'security_groups'), CountableResource('fixed_ips', _fixed_ip_count, 'fixed_ips'), CountableResource('floating_ips', _floating_ip_count, 'floating_ips'), AbsoluteResource('metadata_items', 'metadata_items'), AbsoluteResource('injected_files', 'injected_files'), AbsoluteResource('injected_file_content_bytes', 'injected_file_content_bytes'), AbsoluteResource('injected_file_path_bytes', 'injected_file_path_length'), CountableResource('security_group_rules', _security_group_rule_count_by_group, 'security_group_rules'), CountableResource('key_pairs', _keypair_get_count_by_user, 'key_pairs'), CountableResource('server_groups', _server_group_count, 'server_groups'), CountableResource('server_group_members', _server_group_count_members_by_user, 'server_group_members'), ] QUOTAS.register_resources(resources)

commit_message:
Fix FC case sensitive scanning

For FC connections there are multiple places where we check the
initiator target map provided by the backend against the port names of
the HBAs on the system.

Currently this check is case sensitive, but some backends are returning
the port names in the initiator target map upper cased, which usually
results in attach failures.

Some of the reasons for the attach failures is that os-brick will not
issue scan requests.

Example from a 3PAR backend from a specific system:

  Connector properties:
    {
     'wwpns': ['10001409dcd71ff6', '10001409dcd71ff7'],
     'wwnns': ['20001409dcd71ff6', '20001409dcd71ff7'],
     ...
    }

  Connection properties:
    {
     'initiator_target_map': {
       '10001409DCD71FF6': ['20320002AC01E166', '21420002AC01E166'],
       '10001409DCD71FF7': ['20410002AC01E166', '21410002AC01E166']
     }
     ...
    }

This patch converts to lower case the
initiator_target_map and the target_wwn/target_wwns.

Closes-Bug: #1775677
Change-Id: I12b9535d8a9969356394e406a1ed5ac4a5f1f959
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/78/638178/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Convert wwns to lower case wwns = [wwn.lower() for wwn in wwns] if target_wwns: connection_properties['target_wwns'] = wwns elif target_wwn: connection_properties['target_wwn'] = wwns # Convert it to lower case itmap = {k.lower(): [port.lower() for port in v] for k, v in itmap.items()} connection_properties['initiator_target_map'] = itmap wwpn_lun_map[target_wwpn]))

commit_message:
Adding support of glance cinder store settings

Currently TripleO is completely unaware of the 4 glance
settings when cinder backend of glance is enabled.

To make the Image-Volume in the internal project accessible from
the Image service, the below parameters need to be set.

- cinder_store_auth_address
- cinder_store_project_name
- cinder_store_user_name
- cinder_store_password

Conflicts:
      puppet/services/glance-api.yaml

Closes-Bug: #1809104
Change-Id: I15f9c286798b74529a7b4b09d7e9353eb715f5b1
(cherry picked from commit d9a43277e5266e9d25061a4c16f0384529b46da4)
(cherry picked from commit 02298dd074b480399b15da58ca61fa585df17f75)

commit_message:
Temporary disable scenarios 1+4 standalone for ceph bluestore

We need to merge [1]+[2] for ceph bluestore support. They need each
other but whichever merges first will break the job until the other
merges too. So make [2] depend on this to disable jobs and we revert
after [1] merges

[1] https://review.openstack.org/547682
[2] https://review.openstack.org/637196

Change-Id: I0b25042d67219d096d9928684fd9deb9a5997d39

commit_message:
Use updated Ubuntu installer kernels on MNAIO

Appears we ran into this bug on 16.04:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/debian-installer/+bug/1816876

and the fix is in xenial-updates.  Switching all the ubuntu installer
kernels to the updated ones so that we can make sure we're using
latest and greatest.

Change-Id: I68cccbb142c8b4c657a60929ad21e8164d07a1ef

commit_message:
Change haproxy mode to http for octavia

We should be using 'http' instead of the configured default of tcp as
the transaction mode for octavia.

Change-Id: Ia23e794009b0c69eb9b24d991fa4ab857a00545f
Closes-Bug: #1815603
(cherry picked from commit ec9766716338f20ee94e43074b2369527ba56cf5)

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstacklib refs/changes/07/638907/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- prelude: > In this release Ubuntu has moved all projects that supported it to python3 which means that there will be a lot of changes. The Puppet OpenStack project does not test the upgrade path from python2 to python3 packages so there might be manual steps required when moving to the python3 packages. upgrade: - | Ubuntu packages are now using python3, the upgrade path is not tested by Puppet OpenStack. Manual steps may be required when upgrading.

there is Puppet 4.10.12 as latest we should assume people

commit_message:
Use validate_legacy

This changes all the puppet 3 validate_* functions
to use the validate_legacy function.

The validate_legacy function has been available since
about three years but require Puppet >= 4.4.0 and since
there is Puppet 4.10.12 as latest we should assume people
are running a fairly new Puppet 4 version.

This is the first step to then remove all validate function
calls and use proper types for parameter as described in spec [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568929/

Change-Id: I70b9cafad10ec5abfc0166feb01c49adbd1f517d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-openstacklib refs/changes/63/638863/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: validate_legacy(Hash, 'validate_hash', $policies)

commit_message:
Clean up devstack tempest jobs

- Created new senlin-tempest-base job with devstack-tempest as parent
- Base all senlin tempest jobs on senlin-tempest-base and remove any
  unnecessary settings
- Remove unused playbooks
- Use microversion 1.10 for all tempest jobs

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/635634
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/635621
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/635648

Change-Id: I21998570d0826189a9a019b7cee226560d5388e0

commit_message:
Use validate_legacy

This changes all the puppet 3 validate_* functions
to use the validate_legacy function.

The validate_legacy function has been available since
about three years but require Puppet >= 4.4.0 and since
there is Puppet 4.10.12 as latest we should assume people
are running a fairly new Puppet 4 version.

This is the first step to then remove all validate function
calls and use proper types for parameter as described in spec [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568929/

Change-Id: Ib21fef57404d63579743270be4080d248a4ca8cc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-glance refs/changes/07/638807/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add python3.7 job on Stein+

This is a mechanically generated patch to add a unit test job running
under Python 3.7.

python3.5 was the only supported python3 version on Xenial. Now that
we have Bionic nodes supporting python3.6 and python3.7, let's add
testing with python3.7 in addition to python3.6 in Stein and
beyond.

See ML discussion here [1] for context.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2018-October/135626.html

Change-Id: Id0d0a55f4ceaa05869cb77abf13ee2fea7bee713
Story: #2004073
Task: #27440

commit_message:
Use validate_legacy

This changes all the puppet 3 validate_* functions
to use the validate_legacy function.

The validate_legacy function has been available since
about three years but require Puppet >= 4.4.0 and since
there is Puppet 4.10.12 as latest we should assume people
are running a fairly new Puppet 4 version.

This is the first step to then remove all validate function
calls and use proper types for parameter as described in spec [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568929/

Change-Id: I639f87c524ea7f565a8cc6ddaf331afa284b9e22

commit_message:
mention using CIVS for chair election

If there are multiple candidates for chair, using CIVS like we do for
other community elections gives us a way to have private ballots.

Change-Id: Ifcf3e208f9a01fb4d3b84d05b6d6b8964df3b4de
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

deleted_lines: * monitor and coordinate the discussion and selection of the new chair

commit_message:
Force /var/tmp as the test directory because of xattr

We use xattr a lot. But we don't want to use the current directory
because... no reason. It just seems wrong to pollute a source
diretory with test files. Let's use the root as next bet for
the systems where /tmp is mounted (Fedora 23, for example).

Change-Id: I1cdb4edb0b572360295ec2229a952b281a6cd499
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/08/328508/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // Default for os.TempDir is /tmp, which does not support xattr on F23 fp, err := ioutil.TempFile("/var/tmp", "")

commit_message:
clarify the hand-off of chair responsibilities at election

Be a little more explicit about whether the outgoing or incoming chair
is responsible for a block of tasks. Move the liaison assignment task
to the list of tasks after the incoming chair is confirmed.

Change-Id: Ie9f7b5786e73cda2a55c3978b2058dbd39864689
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

deleted_lines: When the election results are available:After the election results are confirmed: After the chair status is confirmed:

empty server for now, because InfoHandler does not // use any of it. return server } type TestWriter struct { // Duck http.ResponseWriter status int header http.Header body []byte } func (w *TestWriter) Header() http.Header { // if w.header == nil { // w.header = make(http.Header) // } return w.header } // Docs say: // If WriteHeader is not called explicitly, the first call to Write // will trigger an implicit WriteHeader(http.StatusOK). func (w *TestWriter) Write(data []byte) (int, error) { // XXX implement implicit WriteHeader w.body = append(w.body, data...) // inefficient but ok []byte { return w.body } func NewTestWriter() *TestWriter { return &TestWriter{header: make(http.Header)} } func TestInfoGet(t *testing.T) { var err error req, err := http.NewRequest("GET", "/info", nil) require.Nil(t, err) srv := NewTestServer() writer := NewTestWriter() srv.InfoHandler(writer, req) require.Equal(t, writer.status, http.StatusOK) m := new(SwiftSection) err = Not sure how this worked previously, but in the current code
GET to /healthcheck returns 401, unless a token is supplied.

Change-Id: Id6e079c8a0f53374dfdce65338f4b82217769ba2

commit_message:
Make TempAuth to pass accesses to outside of /v1

Not sure how this worked previously, but in the current code
GET to /healthcheck returns 401, unless a token is supplied.
In traditional Swift, authentication is not necessary for that.

Also, drop a useless assignment.

Change-Id: Id6e079c8a0f53374dfdce65338f4b82217769ba2

subject: Fake GetRing in order to test on systems without Swift
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-10-31 03:38:05.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/d18625315bcf2a46b41f92ddf6f1bf189e5b45aa', 'message': 'Fake GetRing in order to test on systems without Swift

If we run on a box without Swift installed, the probe tests
fails with a panic:

  panic: interface conversion: hummingbird.Daemon is nil, not
  *objectserver.Replicator

This occurs because, although we go to certain lengths to prepare
a fake ring, NewReplicator ends calling GetRing for real.
On a system with Swift installed, it actually loads the rings,
and we promptly override them with our fakes. On a system
without Swift it rolls over, and since we ignore its errors,
we panic.

This patch solves the issue by faking GetRing, so that these
postfactum overrides are not needed anymore. Fortunately we
get to reuse all the hard work that went into faking Ring.

Change-Id: Ib844723c154c65229a9d3db06295e975a04bc5de
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-11-20 07:08:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/5c5ea2ac1a1a2593cd243804954987d222a5face', 'message': 'Fake GetRing in order to test on systems without Swift

If we run on a box without Swift installed, the probe tests
fails with a panic:

  panic: interface conversion: hummingbird.Daemon is nil, not
  *objectserver.Replicator

This occurs because, although we go to certain lengths to prepare
a fake ring, NewReplicator ends calling GetRing for real.
On a system with Swift installed, it actually loads the rings,
and we promptly override them with our fakes. On a system
without Swift it rolls over, and since we ignore its errors,
we panic.

This patch solves the issue by faking GetRing, so that these
postfactum overrides are not needed anymore. Fortunately we
get to reuse all the hard work that went into faking Ring.

Change-Id: Ib844723c154c65229a9d3db06295e975a04bc5de
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-11-23 06:21:31.000000000', 'files': ['go/objectserver/replicator_test.go', 'go/probe/base.go', 'go/hummingbird/ring.go'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/5a3c208054555d425b7b5db1e870221b199f45d9', 'message': 'Fake GetRing in order to test on systems without Swift

If we run on a box without Swift installed, the probe tests
fail with a panic:

  panic: interface conversion: hummingbird.Daemon is nil, not
  *objectserver.Replicator

This occurs because, although we go to certain lengths to prepare
a fake ring, NewReplicator ends calling GetRing for real.
On a system with Swift installed, it actually loads the rings,
and we promptly override them with our fakes. On a system
without Swift it rolls over, and since we ignore its errors,
we panic.

This patch solves the issue by faking GetRing, so that these
postfactum overrides are not needed anymore.

A similar thing is happening in the replicator tests. There,
however, we continue to reassign over our (now faked) Rings[],
because we want to have paremeters passed to faking methods.

Change-Id: Ib844723c154c65229a9d3db06295e975a04bc5de
'}]
commit_message:
Fake GetRing in order to test on systems without Swift

If we run on a box without Swift installed, the probe tests
fail with a panic:

  panic: interface conversion: hummingbird.Daemon is nil, not
  *objectserver.Replicator

This occurs because, although we go to certain lengths to prepare
a fake ring, NewReplicator ends calling GetRing for real.
On a system with Swift installed, it actually loads the rings,
and we promptly override them with our fakes. On a system
without Swift it rolls over, and since we ignore its errors,
we panic.

This patch solves the issue by faking GetRing, so that these
postfactum overrides are not needed anymore.

A similar thing is happening in the replicator tests. There,
however, we continue to reassign over our (now faked) Rings[],
because we want to have paremeters passed to faking methods.

Change-Id: Ib844723c154c65229a9d3db06295e975a04bc5de
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/00/391700/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: func GetRing(ringType, prefix, suffix string, policy int) (Ring, error) {

commit_message:
Patch the policy through proxy operations

Surprisingly, we have a perfectly good support for policies, but
the policies are not passed through proxy, so one cannot actually
access anything stored in a container with non-default policy.

This is a simple patch to recrify this by passing policy
information through proxy.

Change-Id: I994d109552e3c31adac82328577a1e72f20c5bda

commit_message:
Add dist-collect and dist: target

This version does
- Make use of $(HUMMINGBIRD_VERSION) in the Makefile.
- Collect swift's own tarball using a workaround of python setup.py sdist.

See https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/golang-infra-issues-to-solve

Change-Id: I5803d5244aef66a9d50f9f619dee86c898b2e586
Do-Not-Merge: true

commit_message:
Add the -s flag to specify hummingbird.conf

This is needed for functional tests that start their own
little object server instead of talking to a pre-existing
cluster. The legacy Swift does this with so-called "in-process"
functional tests, but it avoids the need for flags by running
the servers straight from test processes and patching the
paths with Python methods.

Change-Id: Id3875adf78523c79e404ac37625efdae2369abb3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/16/417216/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Improve the "Server started on port 6200" message

When hummingbird object is run with -v, the message is printed
twice. In addition, the log is prefixed with an uppercase
"ERROR" tag, although there's no error.

I think we may safely drop the extra message. Hopefuly your
management scripts do not depend on it.

Change-Id: I49c9d8c329ab9373a24fe9a7757e07ed5307f687
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/50/418150/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: logger.Err(fmt.Sprintf("Server started on port %d", port)) fmt.Printf("Server started on port %d\n", port)

commit_message:
Generate label with the OpenStack parent project ID for each VM

We previously generated VM endpoint labels indicating the project ID and
project name.  This change adds the parent project ID in the
'projectcalico.org/openstack-project-parent-id' label.

The parent project ID is never included in the Neutron request context,
so unfortunately we can now no longer use that context as a useful
source of project information.  If we haven't cached the information
already, we have to do a Keystone DB lookup.

Change-Id: Iaf7cb7c33c79a0592ea1722a280bc83ca0911fc5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-calico refs/changes/47/635847/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: PROJECT_PARENT_ID_LABEL_NAME = 'projectcalico.org/openstack-project-parent-id'PORT_KEY_PROJ_DATA = 'calico-project-data' self.proj_data_cache = {} self.add_port_project_data(port, context) def add_port_project_data(self, port, context): """add_port_project_data Determine the OpenStack project name and parent ID for a given port's project/tenant ID, and add it as port['calico-project-data']. # If we've already cached the corresponding project data, we're done. proj_data = self.proj_data_cache.get(proj_id) if proj_data is not None: LOG.debug("Project data %r was cached", proj_data) port[PORT_KEY_PROJ_DATA] = proj_data if len(self.proj_data_cache) >= cfg.CONF.calico.project_name_cache_max: self.proj_data_cache = {} # Not cached, so look up the port's project in the Keystone DB. try: wanted_data = None for proj in self.keystone.projects.list(): if proj.id not in self.proj_data_cache: self.proj_data_cache[proj.id] = (proj_name, proj.parent_id) if proj.id == proj_id: wanted_data = self.proj_data_cache[proj.id] if wanted_data is not None: port[PORT_KEY_PROJ_DATA] = wanted_data if PORT_KEY_PROJ_DATA in port: name, parent_id = port[PORT_KEY_PROJ_DATA] labels[PROJECT_NAME_LABEL_NAME] = name labels[PROJECT_PARENT_ID_LABEL_NAME] = parent_id
deleted_lines: PORT_KEY_PROJ_NAME = 'calico-project-name' self.proj_name_cache = {} self.add_port_project_name(port, context) def add_port_project_name(self, port, context): """add_port_project_name Determine the OpenStack project name for a given port's project/tenant ID, and add it as port['calico_project_name']. # If we've already cached the corresponding project name, we're done. proj_name = self.proj_name_cache.get(proj_id) if proj_name is not None: LOG.debug("Project name %r was cached", proj_name) port[PORT_KEY_PROJ_NAME] = proj_name if len(self.proj_name_cache) >= cfg.CONF.calico.project_name_cache_max: self.proj_name_cache = {} # Get the project name from the request context if its available and # matches the port's project ID. cdict = context.to_dict() LOG.info("Request context %s", cdict) req_proj_id = cdict.get('project_id', cdict.get('tenant_id')) req_proj_name = cdict.get('project_name', cdict.get('tenant_name')) if req_proj_id == proj_id and req_proj_name is not None: LOG.info("Got project name %r from request", req_proj_name) port[PORT_KEY_PROJ_NAME] = \ datamodel_v3.sanitize_label_name_value(req_proj_name, PROJECT_NAME_MAX_LENGTH) self.proj_name_cache[proj_id] = port[PORT_KEY_PROJ_NAME] return # Last resort, look up the port's project ID in the Keystone DB. try: wanted_proj_name = None for proj in self.keystone.projects.list(): if proj.id not in self.proj_name_cache: self.proj_name_cache[proj.id] = proj_name if proj.id == proj_id: wanted_proj_name = proj_name if wanted_proj_name is not None: port[PORT_KEY_PROJ_NAME] = wanted_proj_name if PORT_KEY_PROJ_NAME in port: labels[PROJECT_NAME_LABEL_NAME] = port[PORT_KEY_PROJ_NAME]

commit_message:
Use validate_legacy

This changes all the puppet 3 validate_* functions
to use the validate_legacy function.

The validate_legacy function has been available since
about three years but require Puppet >= 4.4.0 and since
there is Puppet 4.10.12 as latest we should assume people
are running a fairly new Puppet 4 version.

This is the first step to then remove all validate function
calls and use proper types for parameter as described in spec [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568929/

Change-Id: I422be4bfb6fd6f73f0b24ae9464c5c85689594e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-heat refs/changes/10/638810/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: validate_legacy(String, 'validate_string', $password)

commit_message:
Doc8: Stop skipping D001: Line too long

This cleans up the cases where we had D001 violations so we can stop
skipping that check in doc8 runs.

Change-Id: Ie52f6ecac1a645fcbcc643b9ca63e033b622d830
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
[NetApp] Fix race condition issue in NetApp driver

This patch fixes the concurrency in the NetApp driver between the
method setup_server and teardown_server by doing the
teardown_server method lock the needed resources correctly.

Closes-bug: #1816640

commit_message:
Use validate_legacy

This changes all the puppet 3 validate_* functions
to use the validate_legacy function.

The validate_legacy function has been available since
about three years but require Puppet >= 4.4.0 and since
there is Puppet 4.10.12 as latest we should assume people
are running a fairly new Puppet 4 version.

This is the first step to then remove all validate function
calls and use proper types for parameter as described in spec [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/568929/

Change-Id: I841fb0c66a891cc936a117ac2d2fd0b82a60fbd1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-horizon refs/changes/11/638811/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: validate_legacy(Hash, 'validate_hash', $api_versions) validate_legacy(Enum['on', 'off'], 'validate_re', [['^on$', '^off$']]) validate_legacy(Enum['legacy', 'angular'], 'validate_re', [['^legacy$', '^angular$']]) validate_legacy(Stdlib::Absolutepath, 'validate_absolute_path', $root_path)

commit_message:
Include standalone deploy logs for logstash index

Standalone deployment log is not indexed by logstash which
makes impossible to investigate errors related to them.

Change-Id: Ia70bf9850fab5a3b92332b4885e895ed98653596
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras refs/changes/78/639078/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - /home/*/standalone_deploy.log - /home/*/standalone_container_prep.log

commit_message:
Add OvnDbInternal to EndpointMap and use it for ovn_db_host

OVN controller/metadata use ovn_dbs_vip hiera key to configure
the central ovn DB. This key is not available on split control
plane or multi cell setup and therefore installation fails.

With this change a new entry gets created in the EndpointMap
named OvnDbInternal. This can then be exported for an overcloud
stack and can be used as an input for the cell stack.

The information from the EndpointMap is used for ovn-metadata
and ovn-controller as the ovn_db_host information in puppet-tripleo

Change-Id: I0d9eb663405d1113ea84e3c12651a3f0dbdfc75d
Closes-Bug: #1817524
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/91/638991/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tripleo::profile::base::neutron::agents::ovn::ovn_db_host: {get_param: [EndpointMap, OvnDbInternal, host_nobrackets]}

commit_message:
Clean up devstack tempest jobs

- Created new senlin-tempest-base job with devstack-tempest as parent
- Base all senlin tempest jobs on senlin-tempest-base and remove any
  unnecessary settings
- Remove unused playbooks
- Use microversion 1.12 for all tempest jobs

Change-Id: I21998570d0826189a9a019b7cee226560d5388e0

commit_message:
Add DISK_GB to compute in SharedStorageFixture

To prepare for tests of the new ?in_tree<N> syntax, this patch adds
DISK_GB inventory to the second compute node provider in the
SharedStorageFixture used in the allocation-candidates gabbits.

Change-Id: I4eb504ad1f0ef8d5caa096460dbd990cc04a8b1f

commit_message:
Replace ansible --sudo with --become in live_migration/hooks scripts

Ansible deprecated --sudo in 1.9 so this change replaces
it with --become.

Change-Id: I40f40766a7b84423c1dcf9d5ed58476b86d61cc4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/635308/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: $ANSIBLE primary --become -f 5 -i "$WORKSPACE/inventory" -m ini_file -a "dest=$BASE/new/tempest/etc/tempest.conf section=compute-feature-enabled option=block_migration_for_live_migration value=False"
